DOC.brief_summary: Although gains have been made in achieving the health-related Millennium Development Goals (MDG), much is still needed in countries affected by high levels of HIV/AIDS. Prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) is a cornerstone strategy in reducing infant mortality from HIV. The study will employ a cluster randomized control trial (cRCT) with 26 health facilities randomized to two arms (intervention or control) to determine the effect of mobile phone technology on completion of key PMTCT milestones from antenatal to six weeks postpartum. The study will examine the acceptability, effectiveness, and cost of implementing a PMTCT-focused mHealth strategy among HIV-infected pregnant women, health workers, and male partners.
DOC.brief_title: Mobile Phone Technology for Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission of HIV: Acceptability, Effectiveness, and Cost
DOC.criteria: Inclusion Criteria (female): HIVpositive pregnant women seeking ANC at a study site Up to 32 weeks gestation Own or have access to a mobile phone on which they can receive calls and SMS messages Exclusion Criteria (female): HIVpositive pregnant women who have already initiated antiretroviral treatment Inclusion Criteria (male): Referral by pregnant female partner
